Welcome to the wonderful world of JUnit.

There are many useful websites fo=
r the JUnit user, but perhaps the two
main ones are http://www.junit.org/ a=
nd http://www.google.com/. The
JUnit site maintains a lot of useful informa=
tion and links to other
resources. Many of the articles there are directed =
towards the
beginner and will help you greatly as you learn about JUnit. Go=
ogle is
useful when there's something you need, but don't know what it is.
=
Just type a description in, press enter and see how much help it can
be. I'=
ve found quite a few useful things that way. Another tip with
Google is to =
search on the specific error message that you have, often
you'll find forum=
 discussions about that exact error, with a good
chance of a solution being=
 given as well.

As you learn and start having questions, you will also fin=
d the JUnit
FAQ very helpful. The questions that it answers really are the
=
frequent ones that most of us had asked or wondered about and Mike
Clark do=
es a wonderful job of collating it. Here is a link:

http://junit.sourcefor=
ge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm

When you are ready to start asking more questions o=
n the JUnit mailing
list, please consider following all of the advice in Er=
ic Raymond's
very helpful document: "How to ask questions the smart way", a=
vailable
at his website. Here is a link:

http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/sma=
rt-questions.html

As far as books are concerned, I recommend Pragmatic Uni=
t Testing by
Hunt and Thomas for beginners. JUnit recipes by Rainsberger is=
 good
once you're past the basics. There are other good books out there, bu=
t
these are my recommendations.

I hope that this helps.

Simon
